bullets.text: Cloud computing is a widely used concept in modern technology.
It is the delivery of computing services (servers, storage, databases, software, etc.) over the internet.
Organizations rent computing resources on demand instead of owning and maintaining physical hardware.
Analogy: paying for electricity consumption without owning the power plant.
On-demand self-service: users access resources without human interaction.
Broad network access: services available over the internet from various devices.
Resource pooling: providers share resources across multiple customers securely.
Rapid elasticity: resources scale up or down quickly based on demand.
Measured service: usage is monitored and billed according to resources consumed.
Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS): Provider delivers fundamental computing resources (VMs, storage, networking). Example: AWS EC2.
Platform as a Service (PaaS): Provider delivers infrastructure plus a development platform. Example: Google App Engine.
Software as a Service (SaaS): Provider delivers ready-to-use applications over the internet. Examples: Gmail, Microsoft 365, Zoom.
Public Cloud: Services delivered over the internet, shared by multiple organizations; cost-effective but may raise security concerns.
Private Cloud: Dedicated to a single organization; offers more control and security but can be more expensive.
Hybrid Cloud: Combines public and private clouds for flexibility and security balance.
Community Cloud: Shared by several organizations with common goals (e.g., healthcare, education).
Advantages: Reduced costs, improved scalability, enhanced flexibility, reliability, and support for innovation.
Challenges: Security and privacy concerns due to remote data storage.
Challenges: Potential downtime affecting access to critical resources.
Challenges: Compliance with industry-specific regulations.
Challenges: Vendor lock-in and performance concerns for high-speed applications.
Data storage and backup (Google Drive, Dropbox).
Business collaboration (Slack, Microsoft Teams).
Entertainment streaming (Netflix, Spotify).
Healthcare (electronic medical records, telemedicine).
Education (Coursera, Google Classroom) and research (large-scale data analysis).
Cloud computing in AI and Big Data analytics provides high-performance computing resources on demand.
Edge computing processes data closer to the source, reducing latency, but still relies on the cloud for management.
Future trends include multi-cloud strategies to avoid vendor lock-in.
Serverless computing allows developers to focus solely on code.
Continued focus on security, compliance, and integration with AI, blockchain, and 5G.
